div.stage: Scene.— Tomb of Proteus in the island of Pharos.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: These are the lovely pure streams of the Nile, which waters the plain and lands of Egypt, fed by white melting snow instead of rain from heaven. Proteus was king of this land when he was alive,

living on the island of Pharos and lord of Egypt; and he married one of the daughters of the sea, Psamathe, after she left Aiakos’ bed. She bore two children in his palace here: a son Theoklymenos, because he spent his life in reverence of the gods,

and a noble daughter, her mother’s pride, called Eido in her infancy. But when she came to youth, the season of marriage, she was called Theonoe; for she knew whatever the gods design, both present and to come,
having received this honor from her grandfather Nereus.
My own fatherland, Sparta, is not without fame, and my father is Tyndareus; but there is indeed a story that Zeus flew to my mother Leda, taking the form of a bird, a swan,

which accomplished the deceitful union, fleeing the pursuit of an eagle, if this story is true. My name is Helen; I will tell the evils I have suffered. For the sake of beauty, three goddesses came to a deep valley on Mount Ida, to Paris:

Hera and Kypris, and the virgin daughter of Zeus, wishing to have the judgment of their loveliness decided. Kypris offered my beauty, if misfortune is beautiful, for Paris to marry, and so she won. Paris, the shepherd of Ida, left his ox-stalls
and came to Sparta, to have me in marriage.

But Hera, indignant at not defeating the goddesses, made an airy nothing of my marriage with Paris; she gave to the son of king Priam not me, but an image, alive and breathing, that she fashioned out of the sky and made to look like me;

and he thinks he has me—an idle fancy, for he doesn’t have me. And in turn the plans of Zeus added further troubles to these; for he brought a war upon the land of the Hellenes and the unhappy Phrygians, so that he might lighten mother earth

of her crowded mass of mortals, and bring fame to the bravest man of Hellas. So I was set up as the Hellenes’ spear-prize, to test the courage of the Trojans; or rather not me, but my name. Hermes caught me up in the folds of the air and

hid me in a cloud—for Zeus was not neglectful of me—and he set me down here in the house of Proteus, having selected the most self-controlled of all mankind, so that I might keep my bed pure for Menelaos. And so I am here, while my wretched husband

has gathered an army and gone over to the towers of Ilion to hunt down and recover me. And many lives have been lost for my sake by the streams of Skamandros; and I who have endured all this am accursed, and have in appearance betrayed my husband

and brought a great war to the Hellenes. Why then am I still alive? I heard the god Hermes declare that I would yet live in the glorious country of Sparta, with my husband—for Hermes knew I never went to Ilion—so that I would not go to bed with another man.

Well, as long as Proteus saw this light of the sun, I was safe from marriage; but now that he is hidden in the dark earth, the dead man’s son hunts after a marriage with me. But I, out of regard to my husband of long ago, am throwing myself down as a suppliant before this tomb of Proteus,
for him to keep my bed safe for my husband, so that, if I bear a name infamous throughout Hellas, at least my body may not incur disgrace here.

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Who holds power over this fortified house? The dwelling is worthy of comparison with Ploutos’,

its royal enclosures and towering buildings. Ah! Oh gods, what sight is here? I see the hateful deadly likeness of the woman who ruined me and all the Achaeans. May the gods spurn you, so much do you look like
Helen! If I were not in a foreign land, you would have died by this well-aimed arrow as a reward for your likeness to the daughter of Zeus.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: What is it, poor man—who are you, that you have turned away from me and loathe me for the misfortunes of that one?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: I was wrong; I gave way to my anger more than I should, for all Hellas hates that daughter of Zeus. Forgive me for what I said, lady.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Who are you? Where have you come from, to visit this land?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: I am one of those unfortunate Achaeans, lady.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Then it is no wonder that you loathe Helen. But who are you and where do you come from? Whose son should I call you?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: My name is Teucer, my father is Telamon, and Salamis is the land that nurtured me.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Then why are you visiting these lands of the Nile?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: I am an exile, driven out of my native land.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You must be unhappy! Who banished you from your fatherland?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: My father Telamon. Could you find anyone closer to me?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: But why? This matter is surely an unfortunate one.

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: The death of my brother Aias at Troy was my ruin.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: How so? You didn’t take his life with your sword, did you?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: He threw himself on his own sword and died.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Was he mad? For what sensible man would dare such a thing?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Do you know a certain Achilleus, the son of Peleus?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Yes; he came to woo Helen once, so I hear.

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: When he died, he left a contest for his armor to his allies.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Well, if he did, what harm is this to Aias?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: When someone else got the arms, he took his own life.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Then are you ill through his suffering?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Yes, because I did not die together with him.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: So you went to the famous city of Ilion, stranger?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Yes, and by helping to sack it, I destroyed myself as well.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Has it already been set alight and completely consumed by fire?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: So that not even a trace of the walls is evident.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: O miserable Helen! Because of you, the Phrygians have been destroyed.

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: And also the Achaeans; great evils have been committed.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: How long is it since the city was sacked?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Almost seven years have gone full circle, with their harvests.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And how much longer were you waiting at Troy?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: For many months; the moon held its course through ten years.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And did you capture the Spartan woman?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Menelaos caught her by the hair to drag her away.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Did you yourself see the wretched creature? Or do you speak from hearsay?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: I saw her with my own eyes, just as I see you, no less.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Consider whether you had some fancy, sent by the gods.

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Think of some other topic, not that woman still!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Are you so sure this fancy was reliable?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: I saw it with my own eyes; and the mind has sight.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Is Menelaos already at home with his wife?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: No; he is neither in Argos nor by the streams of the Eurotas.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Alas! This is evil news for those to whom you bring it.

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: He is said to have disappeared with his wife.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Wasn’t there the same passage for all the Argives?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Yes; but a tempest scattered them in every direction.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: On which surface of the salty ocean?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: While they were crossing the Aegean in mid-channel.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And from that time does no one know of Menelaos’ arrival?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: No one; but throughout Hellas he is reported to be dead.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I am wholly lost. Is the daughter of Thestius alive?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: You speak of Leda? She is dead and gone, indeed.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: It wasn’t Helen’s disgraceful fame that killed her, surely?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Yes, they say she tied a noose around her noble neck.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Are the sons of Tyndareus still alive or not?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: They are dead, and not dead: it is a double story.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Which report is the stronger? I am so unhappy at these evils!

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Men say that they are gods in the likeness of stars.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: That is good news; but what is the other story?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: That they killed themselves because of their sister. But enough of such talk! I do not need to grieve twice. As to why I came to this royal palace,

wanting to see the prophetess Theonoe, you be my patron, so I might obtain an oracle: how I should steer a favorable course to the island of Cyprus, where Apollo has declared I am to live, giving it the island name of
Salamis in honor of that fatherland over there.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: The voyage itself will explain that, stranger; leave this land and escape, before the son of Proteus, the ruler of this land, catches sight of you; now he is away with his trusty hounds tracking his savage quarry to the death;
for he kills every visitor from Hellas that he catches. Do not seek to learn his reason, and I will not say; for how could I help you?

sp.speaker: Teucer
sp.l: Lady, you have spoken well. May the gods grant you a return for your kindness!
Although you have a body like Helen’s, your heart is not like hers, but very different. May she die miserably, and never reach the streams of Eurotas! But may you always have good fortune, lady.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Oh, as I begin the great lament of my great distress,
what mourning shall I strive to utter? or what Muse shall I approach with tears or songs of death or woe? Alas!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Winged maidens, virgin daughters of Earth, the Sirens, may you come to my mourning
with Libyan flute or pipe or lyre, tears to match my plaintive woes; grief for grief and mournful chant for chant, may Persephone send choirs of death
in harmony with my lamentation, so that she may receive as thanks from me, in addition to my tears, a paean for the departed dead beneath her gloomy roof.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Beside the deep-blue water
and on the tangled grass, I happened to be drying purple robes in the sun’s golden blaze near the young reed shoots; from my mistress, from where she cried aloud her misery,

I heard a sound, a mournful song not fit for the lyre, because she was then shrieking, lamenting with her wails; just as a Naiad nymph, who sends a song of woe ringing over the hills, cries out, under the rocky hollows, with screams
at the rape of Pan.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Oh! Oh! Maidens of Hellas, the prey of barbarian sailors! An Achaean sailor
came, he came bringing tears upon tears to me. Ilion has been destroyed and is left to the enemy’s fire through me, the death-giver, through my name, full of suffering.
Leda sought death by hanging, in anguish over my disgrace. My husband, after much wandering in the sea, has died and is gone;
and Castor and his brother, twin glory of their native land, have vanished, vanished, leaving the plains that shook to their galloping horses,
and the schools of reed-fringed Eurotas, scene of youthful labors.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Alas, alas! for your mournful fate and destiny, lady! You were fated, fated to have a life full of pain, when Zeus begot you on your mother,
shining through the air on the wings of a snow-white swan. What evil is not yours? What life have you not endured? Your mother is dead;
the twin beloved sons of Zeus do not enjoy happiness; and you do not see your fatherland, while through the cities a rumor goes, mistress, which hands you over
to the bed of a barbarian; your husband has lost his life in the salty waves, and never again will you bring glee to your father’s halls and Athene of the Bronze House.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Ah! Who was it, either from Phrygia
or from Hellas, who cut the pine that brought tears to Ilion? From this wood the son of Priam built his deadly ship, and sailed by barbarian oars
to my home, to that most ill-fated beauty, to win me as his wife; and with him sailed deceitful and murderous Kypris, bearing death for the Danaans.
Oh, unhappy in my misfortune! But Hera, the holy beloved of Zeus on her golden throne, sent the swift-footed son of Maia. I was gathering fresh rose leaves in the folds of my robe,

so that I might go to the goddess of the Bronze House; he carried me off through the air to this luckless land, and made me an object of miserable strife, of strife between Hellas and the sons of Priam. And my name
beside the streams of Simois bears a false rumor.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: You have sorrows, I know; but it is best to bear as lightly as we can the necessary evils of life.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Dear friends, to what a fate am I yoked? Did my mother bear me as a wonder to mankind? For no other woman, Hellene or barbarian, gives birth to a white vessel of chicks, in which they say Leda bore me to Zeus.

My life and all I do is a wonder, partly because of Hera, and partly my beauty is to blame. If only I could be rubbed out like a painting, and have again in turn a plainer form instead of beauty, and the Hellenes would have forgotten the evil fate that I now have,
and would remember what part of my life is not evil, as they now remember what is.
When someone looks to one event only, and is ill-treated by the gods, it is hard, but all the same it can be borne. But I am involved in countless troubles.

First, although I never acted wrongly, my good name is gone. And this trouble is stronger than the reality, if someone incurs blame for wrongs that are not his own. Next, the gods have removed me from my native country to barbarian habits, and bereft of friends

I have become a slave although I am free by birth; for among barbarians all are slaves except one. And the only anchor of my fortunes is gone, the hope that my husband would come one day and free me of my woes—he is dead, he no longer exists.

My mother is dead, and I am called her murderer—unjustly, but that injustice is mine to bear; while the one who was born the glory of the house, my daughter, is growing gray as a virgin, without a husband; and those two Dioskouroi, called the sons of Zeus, are no more.

But with all my misfortunes, I am as good as dead in my circumstances, though not in fact. And this is the last evil of all: if ever I should come home, I would be shut out by barred doors, for people would think I was that Helen of Troy, coming back with Menelaos.
If my husband were still alive, we could have recognized each other by recourse to tokens which are evident to us alone. But now this is not so, and he can never be saved.
Why then do I still live? What fortune do I have left? Shall I choose marriage in exchange for evils,

and live with a barbarian man, seated at his sumptuous table? But whenever a husband she hates lives with a woman, her own body is also hateful to her. It is best to die; how could this not be well done? To hang oneself, high in the air, is unseemly,

even slaves consider it undignified; but to stab oneself is noble and good, and the moment of rending life from the body is short. For I have come to such a depth of misery; other women have good fortune from their beauty,
but the same thing has destroyed me.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: Helen, do not suppose that stranger who came here, whoever he was, has spoken the whole truth.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And yet he said very clearly that my husband was dead.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: Many words might be said in falsehood also.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And the opposite of falsehood is clear in its truth.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: You are carried towards misfortune instead of what is good.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Yes, for terror has embraced me and leads me to the thing I fear.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: How much goodwill is there in this house for you?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: All are my friends, except the one who hunts me in marriage.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: Then do you know what you should do? Leave your seat at the monument—

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: What sort of word of advice are you coming to?

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: Go inside and question the daughter of the sea-nymph, Theonoe, who knows all things, about your husband, whether he is still alive, or has left the light of day;

and when you know for certain, rejoice or be full of mourning, according to your fortune. Before you know anything correctly, what good would it do you to grieve? But be persuaded by me; leave this tomb and join the girl;

when you have someone in this house from whom you can learn the whole truth, why do you look further? And I myself want to go in and ask about the prophecies of the maiden with you; for, truly, women ought to help each other.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Dear friends, I welcome your advice. Come in, come into the house, to learn within about my struggles.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: You are calling on one who is wholly willing.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Oh, what an unhappy day! What tearful word shall I hear, unhappy as I am?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Do not be a prophetess of sorrow, dear friend, anticipating lamentation.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: What has my poor husband suffered? Does he see the light and the sun’s chariot and the paths of the stars? Or does he have a lasting fate
among the dead beneath the earth?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Take a brighter view of the future, whatever will happen.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: For I call on you, I swear to you, Eurotas green with watery reeds,

if this rumor of my husband’s death is true—and what was obscure in those words?—I will stretch a deadly noose about my neck, or drive inward a murderous thrust of slaughter that gushes from the throat,
a contest of the blade through my flesh, as a sacrifice to the three goddesses and to the son of Priam, who once sat on the hollows of Ida, near the ox-stalls.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: May sorrow be turned aside elsewhere, and may your lot be fortunate!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Oh, unhappy Troy! Through deeds not done by yourself, you are ruined, and have suffered pitiably; for the gift that Kypris gave me has caused much blood

and many tears; it has added grief to grief and tear to tear, sorrows. . . . Mothers have lost their children and virgin sisters of the slain have cut off their hair by the swollen tide of Phrygian Skamandros.
And Hellas has cried aloud, aloud, and broken forth in wailing, beating her head, and drenching her soft-skinned cheek with the bloody strokes of her nails.

O maiden Kallisto, blessed once in Arcadia, who climbed into the bed of Zeus on four paws, how much happier was your lot than my mother’s, you who in the form of a shaggy-limbed beast—the bearing of a lioness with your fierce eye—changed your burden of sorrow;

and also the one whom Artemis once drove from her chorus, as a deer with horns of gold, the Titan girl, daughter of Merops, because of her loveliness; but the beauty of my body has destroyed the Dardanian towers, it has destroyed them and
the lost Achaeans.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: O Pelops, who once held that chariot-race contest with Oinomaos over Pisa, if only, when you were persuaded to make a banquet for the gods, you had left your life then, inside the gods,

before you ever begot my father, Atreus, to whom were born, from his marriage with Airope, Agamemnon and myself, Menelaos, a famous pair; for I believe that I carried a mighty army—and I say this not in boast—in ships to Troy,

no tyrant commanding any troops by force, but leading the young men of Hellas by voluntary consent. And some of these can be counted no longer alive, others as having a joyful escape from the sea, bringing home again names thought to be of the dead.

But I wander miserably over the swelling waves of the gray ocean, ever since I sacked the towers of Ilion; and although I long to come home, I am not thought worthy by the gods to achieve this. I have sailed to Libya’s deserts and all its inhospitable landing-places;
and whenever I draw near my native land, the blast drives me back again, and no favoring wind has ever entered my sails to let me come home.
And now I am cast up on this shore, a miserable shipwrecked sailor who has lost his friends; and my ship is

broken into many pieces against the rocks. But out of its cleverly-wrought fastenings the keel was left, on which I made my difficult escape by an unexpected chance, and also Helen with me, whom I dragged away from Troy. But I do not know the name of this country

and its people; for I was embarrassed to burst into a crowd and make inquiries, and so I concealed these shabby clothes, in shame over my misfortune. For whenever a man of high degree is badly off, he falls into an unaccustomed state which is worse than that of one who has long been unfortunate.

But poverty is wearing me away; for I have neither food, nor clothes around my body; one can compare what I am wearing to rags cast out of the ship. The sea snatched away all the robes I once wore, splendid clothes and ornaments. Deep in a cave

I hid the woman who caused all my troubles, and have come here, after compelling those of my friends who survived to guard my wife. I have come alone, seeking help for those friends there, if I may find it somehow after careful search.

When I saw this home, surrounded by walls, and the majestic gateways of some prosperous man, I came near; sailors can hope to get something from wealthy homes; but from those who have no livelihood—they could not help us, even if they wanted to.
Hello! Is there some gatekeeper who might come from the house and announce my troubles within?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Who’s at the door? Get away from the house and don’t annoy my master by standing at the court-yard gate! Or else you will die because you are
a Hellene, and they have no business here.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: My good woman, you can say these same words in a different tone, for I shall be persuaded; but let go your angry speech.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Go away! Stranger, my orders are to let no Hellene come near this house.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Ah! Do not push me, or thrust me away by force.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: You are to blame, for not heeding what I say.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Announce to your master inside—

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: I think someone would be sorry, if I announced your words.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I come as a shipwrecked man and a guest; such people are safe from violence.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Well, go to some other house instead of this one.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: No; I am going inside. You listen to me.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Know that you’re only causing trouble; and soon you’ll be thrown out by force.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Alas! Where are those glorious armies of mine?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Perhaps you were grand somewhere, but not here.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: O my fortune, how we have been unworthily dishonored.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Why are your eyes wet with tears? To whom are you lamenting?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: To my fortunes, which were happy before this.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Well then, why don’t you go away and give these tears to your friends.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What is this land? Whose palace is this?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Proteus lives here, the land is Egypt.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Egypt? O wretched, that I have sailed here!

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: And why do you blame the bright gleam of the Nile?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I do not blame it; I am sighing for my fate.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Many people are doing badly; you are not the only one.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Is the king you name in the house?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: This is his tomb; his son rules the land.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And where might he be? Abroad, or in the house?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: He is not inside; he is most bitterly opposed to the Hellenes.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What cause does he have? I have felt the consequences of it!

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Helen, the daughter of Zeus, is in this house.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What do you mean? What did you say? Tell me again.

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: The daughter of Tyndareus, who once lived in Sparta.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Where did she come from? What is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: She came here from the land of Lakedaimon.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: When? Surely I have not been robbed of my wife from the cave?

sp.speaker: Old woman
sp.l: Before the Achaeans went to Troy, stranger. But get away from the house; for something is happening within, by which the palace is thrown into confusion. You have not come at the right time; and if my master
catches you, death will be your guest-gift. For I am well-disposed to Hellenes, for all that I spoke harshly to you in fear of my master.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What can I say? For after my former troubles, this present event that I hear of is an unhappy one,

if I have come here, bringing my wife who was taken from Troy, and she is kept safe in the cave, but some other woman who has the same name as my wife lives in this house. She said the woman was born the child of Zeus.

Can there be a man with the name of Zeus by the banks of Nile? For there is only one in heaven. Where in the world is there a Sparta, except by the streams of Eurotas, with its lovely reeds? The name of Tyndareus is the name of one alone.

Is there any land of the same name as Lakedaimon or Troy? I do not know what to say; for there are probably many things in the wide world that have the same names, both cities and women; there is nothing, then, to marvel at.

Besides, I will not run away from a servant’s fears; for no man is so barbaric at heart as to refuse me food when he has heard my name. The fire of Troy is famous, and I, Menelaos, who lighted it, am well known in every land.

I will wait for the master of the house; he gives me two things to look out for: if he is a cruel sort of person, I will keep myself hidden and go back to the shipwreck; but if he shows any softening, I will ask for help in my present state.

This is the worst evil for me in my misery, to beg the means of life from other kings, when I am myself a king; but it is necessary. The saying is not mine, but it is a wise word: nothing is stronger than dreadful necessity.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: I have heard the prophetic maiden, who gave a clear answer within the palace: Menelaos is not yet dead and buried, gone to the land of shadows where darkness takes the place of light;
but he is still wearing out his life on the ocean swell and has not yet reached the haven of his country, wretched in his wandering life,
bereft of every friend, approaching every land in his sea-going ship from the land of Troy.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Here I am, once again coming back to the sanctuary of this tomb, after learning the welcome words of Theonoe,

who knows all things truly; she says my husband is alive and sees the light of day; he is roaming here and there on countless voyages, not without practice in wandering, and he shall come here when he finds an end to his suffering.

But she left one thing unsaid: if he will escape when he has come? And I refrained from asking that question clearly; I was so glad when she told me he was safe. She said that he was near this land somewhere, cast up, shipwrecked, with a few friends.
Oh, when will you come? How much I long for your arrival!
Ah! Who is this? I am not being ambushed by the plots of Proteus’ impious son, am I? Shall I not, like a young racehorse or a worshipper of Bacchus, reach the tomb? There is something wild
about the looks of this man who is hunting me down.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You there! the one trying with fearful effort to reach the base of the tomb and the pillars of burnt sacrifice, stay where you are. Why do you flee? I am amazed and speechless at the sight of your body.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Women, I am being ill-treated. This man is keeping me from the tomb, and he wants to take me and give me to the king, whose wooing I was seeking to avoid.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I am no thief, nor a servant of evil men.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And yet the clothes you are wearing are unsightly enough.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Put fear aside and stop your rapid flight.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I do so, now that I have reached this spot.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Who are you? Whom do I see in you, lady?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: But who are you? The same reason prompts us both.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I never saw a closer resemblance.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: O gods! For the recognizing of friends is a god.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Are you a woman from Hellas, or a native of this land?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: From Hellas; but I want to learn your story too.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You seem to me very much like Helen, lady.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And you seem to me like Menelaos; I don’t know what to say.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Well, you have correctly recognized a most unfortunate man.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Oh, at last you have come to the arms of your wife!

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What do you mean by wife? Do not touch my robe.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: The one whom Tyndareus, my father, gave to you.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: O torch-bearing Hekate, send visions that are favorable!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You see in me no specter of the night, attendant on the queen of phantoms.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: As one man, I am certainly not the husband of two women.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You are the master of what other wife?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: The one hidden in the cave, whom I am bringing from Troy.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You have no other wife but me.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Can it be that I am in my right mind, but my sight is failing?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Don’t you think that when you look at me you see your wife?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Your body resembles hers, but the real truth robs me of this belief.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Look; what more do you need? Who knows better than you?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You are like her; I will not deny that at least.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Who then shall teach you, if not your own eyes?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: It is there that I am ailing, because I have another wife.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I did not go to Troy; that was a phantom.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And who fashions living bodies?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: The air, out of which you have a wife that the gods labored over.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What god’s handiwork? You are saying things beyond hope.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Hera’s, as a substitute, so that Paris would not have me.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: How then could you be here and in Troy at the same time?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: The name may be in many places, though not the body.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Let me go! I have come here with enough pain.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Will you leave me, and take that phantom bride away?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Yes, and fare well, for your likeness to Helen.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I am ruined! I found you, my husband, but I will not have you.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: The greatness of my troubles over there convinces me; you do not.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Ah me! Who was ever more miserable than I am?
Those whom I love best are leaving me, and I shall never reach the Hellenes or my own country.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: (entering hurriedly.)Menelaos, I find you, after taking great trouble to look for you, wandering over the whole of this foreign land; I am sent by the comrades whom you left behind.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What is it? Surely you are not being plundered by the foreigners?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: It is a miracle; what I say is of less account than what happened.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Tell me; for, judging by this eagerness, you are certainly bringing something new.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: I say that you have suffered countless labors in vain.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You are mourning over old sorrows; what is your message?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Your wife has disappeared, taken up into the folds of the unseen air; she is hidden in heaven, and as she left the hallowed cave where we were keeping her, she said this: Miserable Phrygians, and all the Achaeans! On my account you were dying by the banks of Skamandros,

l.q: through Hera’s contrivance, for you thought that Paris had Helen when he didn’t. But I, since I have stayed my appointed time, and kept the laws of fate, will now depart into the sky, my father; but the unhappy daughter of Tyndareus,
guilty in no way, has borne an evil name without reason.

sp.l: Welcome, daughter of Leda, were you here after all? I was just announcing your departure up to the hidden starry realms, not knowing that you had a winged body. I will not let you mock us like this again,
for you gave your fill of trouble to your husband and his allies in Ilion.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: This is the meaning of that; her words have turned out to be true. O longed-for day, that has given you to my arms!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: O Menelaos, dearest of men, the time was long, but delight is just now ours.
With joy I have found my husband, friends, I have embraced my dear one, after long days of blazing light.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And I have found you; but I have many questions about t; now I do not know what to begin with first.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I am so happy, the hair rises on my head and my tears run down. I fling my arms around your neck,
dear husband, to have my delight.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: O dearest sight! I have no fault to find: I have my wife, the daughter of Zeus and Leda; your brothers on their snow-white steeds

blessed you, blessed you at an earlier time, while torches blazed, but the god who took you from my home is driving us on to another fortune, better than this. An evil that was good brought you together with me, your husband
after a long time, but may I still benefit by my good luck.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: May you benefit indeed, and I join in the same prayer; for when there are two, it is not possible for one to be unhappy and the other not.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: My dear friends, I no longer sigh or grieve over what is past.
I have my husband, for whom I have been waiting to come from Troy for many years.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You have me, and I have you; although it was hard to live through so many days, I now understand the actions of the goddess. My joy is tearful; it has more
delight than sorrow.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: What can I say? What mortal could ever have hoped for this? I hold you to my heart, little as I ever thought to.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And I hold you, whom we thought to have gone to Ida’s city and the unhappy towers of Ilion.
By the gods, how were you taken from my home?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Ah! ah! You are setting out on a bitter beginning. Ah! ah! You are asking about a bitter tale.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Speak; all gifts from the gods should be heard.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I detest the story I am now to introduce.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Tell it anyway. It is sweet to hear of troubles.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Not to the bed of the young barbarian, on the wings of oars, on the wings of desire for lawless marriage—

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What god or fate tore you from your country?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Ah, my husband! The son of Zeus, of Zeus, brought me to the Nile.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Amazing! Who sent you there? O dreadful story!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I have wept bitterly, and my eyes are wet with tears; the wife of Zeus ruined me.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Hera? Why did she want to bring trouble to the two of us?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Alas for my terrible fate, the baths and springs, where the goddesses brightened the beauty from which the judgment came.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Regarding the judgment, Hera made it a cause of these troubles for you?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: To take me away from Paris—

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: How? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: To whom Kypris had promised me.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: O unhappy one!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Unhappy, unhappy; and so she brought me to Egypt.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Then she gave him a phantom instead, as I hear from you.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Sorrow, sorrow to your house,
mother, alas.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: My mother is no more; through shame of my disgraceful marriage she tied a noose around her neck.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Alas! Is our daughter Hermione alive?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Ah, my husband! Unmarried, and without children, she mourns my
fatal marriage.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: O Paris, who utterly destroyed my whole house, these things ruined you also, and countless bronze-clad Danaans.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: The god cast me out, ill-fated and accursed, from my country,
from my city, and from you, when I left my home and bed—yet I did not leave them—for a shameful marriage.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: If indeed you should find happiness in the future, it would be a match for the past.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Menelaos, give me as well a share of that joy which I understand, but not clearly.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Come and take part in our talk, old man, you too.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: This woman is not the arbitrator of all the trouble in Troy?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: She is not; I was tricked by the gods
and had in my arms the baneful image of a cloud.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: What are you saying? We suffered in vain for the sake of a cloud?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: It was the work of Hera, and the rivalry of the three goddesses.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: And the one who is truly your wife is this woman here?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: This is she; trust my word for that.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: O daughter, how intricate and hard to trace out is the nature of the god! In some way that is good, he twists everything about, now up, now down; one man suffers, and one who has not suffered comes afterwards to a bad end,

having no security in his current fortune. You and your husband have had your share of trouble, you in repute, he in the heat of battle. In his eagerness, while he was eager, he got nothing; but now that he has achieved the greatest good fortune, he has it without cause.

You did not, after all, bring shame upon your old father or on the twin sons of Zeus, nor did you do such things as were spoken of. Now again I renew your wedding rites and remember the blazing torch I bore, running beside the four yoked horses; and you,

in the chariot as a bride, were leaving your happy home with this man here. Whoever pays no reverence to his master’s affairs, rejoicing with him and grieving with his troubles, is worthless. Although I was born a servant, let me still be numbered among honest
slaves; my mind is free, if not my name. For this is better than to suffer double misery as one man: to have a worthless heart and, being a slave, to owe obedience to any other.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Come, old man—often by my shield

you have had your full share of trouble and hard work—now also have a share in my success, and go tell the friends I left behind the state of matters here, as you found them, and how my fortune stands; and bid them wait at the beach and watch eagerly for the

struggle which I expect awaits me; and if we should be able somehow to steal this woman away from the land, tell them to keep good watch so that we may share the luck and escape, if we can, from the barbarians.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: It shall be done, lord. Now indeed I see how worthless

the seers’ doings are, and how full of falsehood; there was no health in the blaze of sacrifice after all, or in the cry of winged birds; even to think that birds can help mankind is certainly foolish. For Calchas gave no word or sign to the army,

when he saw his friends dying on behalf of a cloud, nor did Helenos; but the city was taken by storm in vain. You might say: because the god did not want them to? Then why do we consult prophets? We ought to sacrifice to the gods and ask a blessing, but leave divination alone;
for this was invented otherwise, as a bait for a livelihood, and no man grows rich by sacrifices if he is idle. But sound judgment and discernment are the best of seers. Exit Messenger.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: My views about seers coincide exactly with this old man’s; whoever has the gods as friends
would have the best prophecy at home.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: All right; so far all is well. But how you were saved, my poor husband, from Troy, there is no gain in knowing, yet friends have a desire to learn what their friends have suffered.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Truly you have asked a great deal all at once. Why should I tell you about our losses in the Aegean, and Nauplios’ beacons on Euboia, and my visits to Crete and the cities of Libya, and the mountain-peaks of Perseus? For I would not satisfy you with the tale,
and by telling you these evils I would suffer still, as I did when I experienced them; and so my grief would be doubled.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Your answer is better than my question. Leave out the rest, and tell me only this: how long were you a weary wanderer over the surface of the sea?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Besides those ten years in Troy, I went through seven cycles of years on board ship.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Alas, poor man, you have spoken of a long time; and, saved from there, you have come here to the slaughter.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What do you mean? What will you say? Ah, my wife, you have ruined me.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Escape from this land and flee as quickly as possible. The man who lives in this house will kill you.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What have I done to deserve such a fate?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You have come unexpectedly to hinder my marriage.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What! Does someone plan to marry my wife?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And to act in violence against me, which I have endured.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Does he have private power, or is he the ruler of the country?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: He is the lord of this land, the son of Proteus.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: This is that riddle I heard from the servant.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Which one of the barbarian’s gates were you standing beside?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: This one, from which I was being driven away like a beggar.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You were surely not begging for food, were you? How unhappy I am!

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: That was the deed, though it did not have that name.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Then you know everything, it seems, about my marriage.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I do. But if you have escaped his bed—that I do not know.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Know that I have saved myself untouched for you.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What could persuade me of this? If true, your words are sweet.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Do you see my wretched sanctuary at this tomb?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I see a miserable bed of straw, but what do you have to do with it?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Here, as a suppliant, I am asking for an escape from his bed.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: For want of an altar, or because it is the barbarians’ way?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: This was as good a protection to me as the temples of the gods.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Then it’s not possible for me to take you home by ship?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: A sword is waiting for you, rather than my bed.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: So I would be the most wretched of mortals.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Do not feel shame now, but escape from this land.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Leaving you behind? I ravaged Troy for your sake.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Yes, for that is better than that our union should cause your death.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Oh! these are coward’s words, unworthy of those days at Troy.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You could not kill the tyrant, your possible intention.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Does he then have a body that cannot be wounded by a sword?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You will hear. But to undertake impossibilities is no mark of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And so I am to offer my hands to be bound, in silence?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You are in a dilemma; we need some contrivance.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Yes, for it is sweeter to die in action than by not acting.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: There is one hope, and only one, for our safety.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Are we to buy it, or dare it, or win it with words?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: If the tyrant were not to learn of your arrival.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Will any one tell him about me? He will certainly not know who I am.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: He has within an ally equal to the gods.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: A voice that has settled in the inmost parts of his house?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: No, but his sister; she is called Theonoe.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: The name is prophetic; tell me what she does.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: She knows everything, and she will tell her brother that you are here.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: We must die; for I cannot escape her notice.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Perhaps we might persuade her by supplication—

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: To do what? What hope are you leading me to?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Not to tell her brother that you are here in this land.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: If we persuade her, could we get away from this country?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Easily, in common with her; but secretly we could not.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: The task is yours; it is suitable for women to deal with women.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Be sure that I will clasp her knees.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Well, then, what if she rejects our proposals?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You will die. And I, the unhappy one, will be married by force.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You would be a traitor; that force of yours is all an excuse.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: But I have sworn a sacred oath by your life—

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What do you mean? To die? And never to take his bed in exchange for mine?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Yes, by the same sword; I will lie at your side.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Then on these conditions touch my right hand.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I touch it, swearing that I will leave the light of day if you die.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And I will end my life if I lose you.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: How then shall we die so as to insure our reputation for this?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I will kill you on the tomb’s surface, and then kill myself. But first I will fight a great contest for your bed. Let anyone who wishes come near!

For I will not disgrace my Trojan fame, nor, on my return to Hellas, will I receive great blame—I who robbed Thetis of Achilleus, and saw the slaughter of Aias, son of Telamon, and the son of Neleus made childless;

shall I not resolve to die for my wife? Most certainly; for if the gods are wise, they lightly bury in the earth a brave man who has been killed by his enemies, while cowards they cast up out of the earth onto a harsh rock.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: O gods, may the race of Tantalos be fortunate at last, and may it be set free from evils!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Ah, I am unhappy, for so is my fate! Menelaos, we are destroyed. The prophetess Theonoe is coming out of the house; it resounds as the

bolts are unfastened. Try to escape! But what is the use of trying? For whether she is absent or present she knows of your arrival here. Oh, I am lost, unfortunate! Saved from Troy and from a barbarian land, you have come only to fall upon barbarian swords.

sp.speaker: Theonoe
sp.l: Please lead the way with blazing torches, and purify, according to the sacred law, the inmost corners of the air, so I may receive the pure breath of heaven; and you in turn, if someone has harmed the path by treading with unholy foot, submit it to the cleansing fire,
and strike the torch in front of me, so that I may pass through. And when you have paid back to the gods my customary observance, take the household flame within.
Helen, what about my prophecy—how is it? This man, your husband Menelaos, has openly arrived,

robbed of his ships and of your counterfeit. O unhappy man! What troubles you have escaped to come here; nor do you know whether you are to return home or to stay here. For there will be strife among the gods, and a solemn assembly held by Zeus on your account this very day.

Hera, who was hostile to you before, is now friendly and wants to bring you safely home, with this woman, so that Hellas may learn that the marriage of Paris, Kypris’ gift, was false; but Kypris wishes to ruin your journey home,

so that she may not be convicted, or seem to have bought the prize of beauty by a marriage that was profitless as regards Helen. Now the decision rests with me, whether to ruin you, as Kypris wishes, by telling my brother of your presence here, or to save your life by taking Hera’s side,
keeping my brother in the dark, for his orders are for me to tell him, whenever you happen to come to this land.
One of you, go show my brother this man is here, so that I may secure my position.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Maiden, I fall at your knees as a suppliant,

and seat myself in this sad posture on behalf of myself and of this man; I am on the point of seeing him slain, after I have found him with such difficulty. Please do not tell your brother that my husband has returned to my loving arms,

but save us, I beseech you; do not forsake the piety that was once yours for your brother’s sake, buying favors that are wicked and unjust. For the god hates violence, and commands everyone to have their possessions without robbery.

Wealth that is unjust, though it may bring some power, ought to be avoided. Heaven is common to all mortals, and so is the earth, where people ought to fill up their homes without having another’s property, or taking it away by force.

At a critical time, but unhappily for me, Hermes gave me to your father to keep safe for my husband, this man who is here and wishes to have me back. But how could he recover me if he is dead? How could your father ever restore the living to the dead? Now examine the will of the god and of your father;

would the deity and your dead father be willing to give back again their neighbor’s goods, or would they not? I think they would. It is not, therefore, right that you should attach more importance to a thoughtless brother more than a good father. If you, who are a prophet and believe in divine affairs,

ruin the lawful intention of your father and gratify your lawless brother, it is disgraceful that you should have full knowledge of divine matters, both what is and what will be, and yet not know what is right. Save me, the unhappy one, enveloped in these troubles,

and give me this addition to my fate; for there is no mortal who does not hate Helen; I am famous throughout Hellas as the one who betrayed my husband and lived in Phrygia’s golden halls. If I come to Hellas and set foot once more in Sparta,

they will hear and see how they were ruined by the wiles of gods, while I was no traitor to my friends after all; and so they will lead me back to virtue again, and I shall betroth my daughter, whom no man now will marry; and, leaving this bitter beggar’s life here, shall enjoy the goods that are in my home.
And if this man were dead and slaughtered on a funeral pyre, I would be cherishing his memory with tears far away; but shall I be robbed of him when he is now alive and safe?
Ah! not that, maiden, I beseech you:
grant me this favor, and imitate the character of a just father; for this is the fairest glory for children, when the child of a good father resembles its parents in character.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: The arguments here proposed are worthy of pity,
and so are you. But I am anxious to hear what Menelaos will say to save his life.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: I could not endure to fall at your knees, or wet my eyes with tears; for if I were cowardly, I would greatly dishonor Troy.

And yet they say that it is fitting for a noble man to let tears fall from his eyes in misfortune. But I will not choose this honorable course, if it is honorable, in preference to bravery. But, if you think it right to save a stranger

seeking justly to recover his wife, then restore her and save us in addition; if not, I would be wretched, not now for the first time but as often before, and you will seem to be an evil woman. What I consider honest and worthy of me,
and what will touch your heart most closely, these things I will say at the tomb of your father, with regret for his loss.
Old man, dwelling in this tomb of stone, give her back, I demand of you my wife, whom Zeus sent here for you to keep for me.

I know you will never restore her to me yourself, for you are dead; but this woman here will not think it right that her father, invoked from below, once so glorious, should bear a tarnished name; for she is the one in authority now.
You, too, Hades of the world below, I call as an ally;

you who have received so many bodies slain by my sword for Helen’s sake, you have your payment; either restore them to life again now, or compel this woman to show herself better than her pious father, and give me back my wife.

But if you will rob me of her, I will tell you what she omitted in her speech. So that you may know, maiden, I am bound by an oath, first to go into battle with your brother; he or I must die; the matter is simple.

If he refuses to meet me face to face, but hunts us down, two suppliants at the tomb, by starvation, I am resolved to kill this woman, and then to plunge this two-edged sword through my heart, on the surface of the tomb, so that streams of blood may

run down the grave; we will lie, two corpses side by side upon this polished slab, a deathless grief to you, and a reproach to your father. Your brother will never marry this woman, nor will any other; but I will carry her off,
if not to my house, at any rate to death.

Why do I say this? If I turned to women’s ways with tears, rather than being active, I would be pitied more. Kill me, if it seems good to you; you will not kill those who are without fame; but it is better to yield to what I say,
so that you may act with justice, and I recover my wife.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: You must judge these arguments, maiden. Decide in such a way as to please all.

sp.speaker: Theonoe
sp.l: My nature and my inclination lean towards piety; and I respect myself, and I would not defile
my father’s fame, or gratify my brother at the cost of seeming infamous. There is a great temple of justice in my nature; and having this heritage from Nereus, I will try to keep it, Menelaos.

Since Hera wishes to serve you, I will cast my vote on her side. May Kypris be gracious to me; but she has had nothing to do with me, and I will try to remain a virgin always. As for your reproaches against my father at this tomb,
I have the same words to say. I would be doing wrong if I do not give her back; for that man, if he were alive, would have given her back for you to have, and you to her.
For truly there is retribution for these things, both among the dead and among all men living. The mind

of the dead does not live, yet it has eternal thought as it falls into eternal ether. So as not to give advice at length, I will be silent as to what you have entreated, and I will never aid my brother’s folly with my counsel.

For I am doing him a service, though he does not think it, if I turn him from his godless life to holiness. You yourselves devise some course of action; I will stand out of your way by my silence. Begin with the gods, and beg

Kypris to allow you to return to your country, and Hera that her intention to save you and your husband may remain the same. And you, my own dead father, never, as far as I have strength, shall you be called impious instead of pious. Exit Theonoe.

sp.speaker: Chorus Leader
sp.l: No one born lawless ever prospered, but in a lawful cause there is hope of safety.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Menelaos, as far as the maiden is concerned, we are safe. For the rest, you must contribute your advice and frame a device to save ourselves.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Then listen; you have been in the house for a long time and are intimate with the king’s servants.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: What do you mean by that? You are offering hope, as if you were really about to do something useful for both of us.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Could you persuade someone in charge of the wagons
and horses to give us a chariot?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I might; but how will we escape, in our ignorance of the country and the barbarian land?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You are right; a dilemma. Well, what if I were to hide in the house and kill the king with this two-edged sword?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: His sister would never be silent or allow you to intend her own brother’s death.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Nor indeed is there a ship in which we might safely escape; for the sea holds the one we had.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Listen to me, if even a woman can say something wise.
Are you willing to be called dead in word, though you are not dead?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: It is a bad omen; but if I profit by it, I am ready to be called dead in word, though I am not dead.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: And truly I would mourn you, as women do, with hair cut short and laments before this impious man.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: What saving remedy does this have for us two? There is a flavor of deception in your scheme.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I will beg the tyrant of this country for permission to bury you in an empty tomb, as if you had really died at sea.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Soppose he allows it; then how shall we escape with no ship,
when we have buried my body in the empty tomb?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I will urge him to give me a vessel, from which I shall have the offerings from your tomb let down into the sea’s embrace.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You have spoken well, except for one thing: if he commands you to set up a tomb on the dry land, your pretext comes to nothing.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: But I will say it is not the custom in Hellas to bury those who have died at sea on the dry land.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You are setting this right, too; then I will sail with you, and help let down the funeral offerings, in the same ship.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You must above all be at hand,
with your sailors who escaped from the wreck.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Be sure that if I have a ship at anchor, they will be posted, man beside man, each with his sword.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You must direct everything; only let there be winds in our sails to guide us, and a speedy ship.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: It will be so; for the deities will bring my troubles to an end. But from whom will you say that you heard I was dead?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: From you; allege that you were the only one to escape death, when you were sailing with the son of Atreus, and that you saw him dead.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: It is true that these rags thrown around my body
will bear witness with me as to the shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: They have come at the right time, although then they seemed an ill-timed loss. Perhaps that misery may turn to good fortune.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Should I to enter the house with you, or am I to sit quietly here at this tomb?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Stay here; for if he does something harsh to you, this tomb and your sword would protect you. But I will go into the house, cut off my hair, exchange my white robe for a dark one, and tear my cheek with nails that make the flesh bloody.
For the contest is a great one, and I see two turns of the scale: either I must die if I am detected in my plot, or else come home and save you as well.
Lady Hera, you who lie in the bed of Zeus, grant relief from their labors to two pitiable creatures;

we beg you, casting our arms straight towards heaven, where you have your home in an embroidery of stars. And you, who won the prize of beauty at the price of my marriage, Kypris, daughter of Dione, do not destroy me utterly. You have maltreated me enough before now,

handing over my name, though not my body, to barbarians. Let me die, if you want to kill me, in my native land. Why are you so insatiable for mischief, practising arts of love, deceits, and treacherous schemes, and magic spells that bring bloodshed on families?
If you were only moderate, in other ways you are by nature the sweetest of gods for men; I don’t deny it. Exeunt Helen and Menelaos.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Let me call on you, beneath leafy haunts, sitting in your place of song, you, the most sweetly singing bird,
tearful nightingale, oh, come, trilling through your tawny throat, to aid me in my lament, as I sing the piteous woes of Helen and
the tearful fate of Trojan women under the Achaeans’ spears; when he sped over the surging plains with foreign oar, when he came, came bringing to Priam’s race from Lacedaemon
you, Helen, his unhappy bride—Paris, fatally wedded, under the guidance of Aphrodite.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Many of the Achaeans have breathed out their last amid the spears and hurling stones and have gone to unhappy Hades; their wives have cut off their hair in sorrow,
and their homes are left without a bride; an Achaean man, who had only a single ship, lit a blazing beacon on sea-girt Euboia, and destroyed many of them, casting them onto the rocks of Kaphareus

and the sea-shores of the Aegean, by the treacherous flame he kindled. The mountains of Malea provided no harbor, in the gusts of the storm, when Menelaos sped far away from his country, bearing on his ships a prize of the barbarian expedition, no prize but strife
with the Danaans, Hera’s holy phantom.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: What is god, or what is not god, or what is in between— what mortal says he has found it by searching the farthest limit,
when he sees divine affairs leaping here and there again and back, in contradictory and unexpected chances? You, Helen, are the daughter of Zeus;
for a winged father begot you in Leda’s womb; and then you were proclaimed throughout Hellas, betrayer, faithless, lawless, godless. I do not know whatever certainty is among mortals,
but the word of the gods I have found true.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: You are fools, who try to win a reputation for virtue through war and marshalled lines of spears, senselessly putting an end to mortal troubles;
for if a bloody quarrel is to decide it, strife will never leave off in the towns of men; by it they won as their lot bed-chambers of Priam’s earth, when they could have set right by discussion
the strife over you, O Helen. And now they are below in Hades’ keeping, and fire has darted onto the walls like the bolt of Zeus, and you are bringing woe on woe . . . .

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Greetings, tomb of my father! For I buried you, Proteus, in the passageway so that I could address you; and always as I leave and enter the house, I, your son Theoklymenos, call on you, father. You servants, take the hounds and hunting nets
into the palace. I have rebuked myself many times; for do we not punish evil men with death? And now I have heard that some Hellene has come openly to the land, without the guards’ notice,

either as a spy or thievishly hunting after Helen; he will die if only I can catch him. Ah! But it seems I have found everything in ruins; for the daughter of Tyndareus has deserted her seat at the tomb and has been carried away from the land.

Ho there! undo the bars; loose the horses from their stalls, servants, and bring out my chariot, so that the wife whom I long for may not be carried away from this land without my notice, for want of effort.
Wait! for I see that the one I am pursuing
is still in the house, and has not fled.
You there, why have you put black robes instead of white on your body, and cut the hair from your noble head with a sword, and why do you drench your cheeks with pale tears,
lamenting? Do you mourn, persuaded by dreams in the night, or have you broken your heart with grief because you heard some voice within?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: My lord—for now I give you that name—I am destroyed; everything of mine is gone and I am nothing.

sp.speaker: Theokylmenos
sp.l: In what misfortune are you plunged? What has happened?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Menelaos—alas, how shall I say it?—is dead, my husband.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: I do not rejoice at your words, but it is good fortune for me. How do you know? Did Theonoe tell you this?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Both she, and one who was there when he perished.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Someone has come who announces this for certain?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Someone has come; and may he go where I want him to go!

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Who is it? Where is he? so that I may learn this more clearly.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: That one, who is sitting crouched at this tomb.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Apollo! He certainly has unattractive clothing.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Alas! I think my husband is in the same situation also.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: What is this man’s country, and where did he come from, to land here?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: He is a Hellene, one of the Achaeans who saiIed with my husband.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: What kind of death does he say Menelaos died?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: The most piteous, in the watery waves at sea.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: On what part of the barbarous ocean was he sailing?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: He was cast up on the harborless rocks of Libya.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: How did this man not perish if he was sailing with him?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: There are times when common men have more luck than their betters.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Where did he leave the wreckage of his ship before coming here?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Where ruin may come upon it— but not on Menelaos!

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: He is already ruined. In what ship did this man come?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Sailors happened to meet him and took him up, as he says.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Where then is that mischievous creature that was sent to Troy in your place?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You mean the cloud image? It has gone into the air.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: O Priam, and Trojan lands, how you have perished in vain!

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I too have shared misfortunes with Priam’s race.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Did he leave your husband unburied, or did he hide him in the earth?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: He is unburied; I am so unhappy in my troubles!

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: It is for this that you have cut your locks of golden hair?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Yes, for he is dear to me, whoever he is, being here.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: She rightly weeps for this misfortune. . .

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: It is certainly easy to escape your sister’s notice!

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: No, indeed. Well, what now? Will you continue to live at this tomb?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Why do you jeer at me? Won’t you let the dead man be?

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: No, for you are loyal to your husband and avoid me.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: No longer; begin my wedding now.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: It has come after a long time, but still I commend you for it.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Do you know what you should do? Let us forget what is past.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: On what terms? One good turn deserves another.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Let us make a truce; be reconciled to me.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: I relinquish my quarrel with you; may it go away on wings.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Now by your knees, since you are indeed a friend—

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: What thing do you hunt after, that you stretch out a suppliant hand to me?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I wish to bury my dead husband.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: What? Is there a tomb for the absent? Or will you bury a shadow?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: It is customary among the Hellenes, whenever someone dies at sea—

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: To do what? The race of Pelops is certainly clever in such matters.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: To carry out the funeral rites in empty woven robes.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Hold the funeral; set up the tomb wherever you wish.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: We do not give burial like this to sailors who have perished.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: How then? I know nothing of the customs in Hellas.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: We take out of harbor to the sea all that is the dead man’s due.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Then what am I to give you for the dead man?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: This man knows, but I have no experience, as I was fortunate before.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Stranger, you have brought welcome news.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Not for me, certainly, nor for the dead man.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: How do you bury those who have died at sea?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Each according to his means.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: As far as wealth goes, say what you want, for her sake.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: There must be a blood-offering first to the dead.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Blood of what? Explain it to me, and I will obey.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: You decide that yourself; whatever you give will suffice.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Among barbarians it is customary to sacrifice a horse or a bull.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: If you make a gift, take care to give nothing mean.

sp.speaker: Theokylemnos
sp.l: I have no lack of such in my rich herds.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Next, a couch empty of the body is decked and carried in procession.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: It wall be done; what else is it customary to add?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Bronze arms; for war was his delight.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: These will be worthy of the race of Pelops, and these we will give.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: And for the rest, all the lovely offspring that the earth bears.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: How then? In what way do you let them fall into the waves?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: A ship must be ready, and rowers.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: How far from the shore does the ship put out?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: So far that the foam in her wake can scarcely be seen from the land.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: But why? Why does Hellas observe this custom.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: So that the waves may not wash pollution back ashore.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: A swift Phoenician ship will be there.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: That would be well done, and pleasing to Menelaos, too.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Can you not perform these rites well enough without Helen?

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: This task belongs to mother, or wife, or children.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: According to you, the work of burying her husband belongs to her.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: Yes indeed; piety demands that the dead be not robbed of their due.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Let her go; it is in my interest to foster piety in a wife. Go inside and choose adornment for the dead;

I will not send you away from the land empty-handed either, since you have done her a favor. As you have brought me good news, you will receive clothing instead of going in rags, and food, so that you may reach your country, since now I see you doing very badly indeed.
As for you, poor lady, do not wear yourself out in a hopeless case; Menelaos has met his doom, and your dead husband could not return to life.

sp.speaker: Menelaos
sp.l: This is your duty, young woman; you must be content with the husband at your side, and let go the one that no longer exists;

for this is best for you, according to what has happened. And if I come to Hellas and find safety, I will put to an end your former bad reputation, if you are such a wife as you ought to be to your husband.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: I will; my husband will never find fault with me;

you yourself will be at hand to know it. Now go inside, unhappy man, and find the bath, and change your clothes. I will show my kindness to you without delay. For you will perform the due services with more kindly feeling for my dearest Menelaos,
if you get from me what you ought to have. Exeunt Theoklymenos, Helen, Menelaos.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Once with swift foot the mountain mother of the gods rushed through the wooded glen, and the river’s streams
and the deep-thundering sea wave, yearning for her lost daughter, whose name may not be spoken. The loudly rattling castanets cried out a shrill sound,
when they, swift-footed as whirlwinds, followed the goddess on her chariot yoked to wild creatures, after the girl that was snatched away from the circling chorus of maidens—
here Artemis with her bow, and there the grim-eyed goddess, in full armor, with her spear. But Zeus, who sees clearly from his throne in heaven, brought to pass another destiny.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: When the mother ceased from her wild
wandering toil, searching for the treacherous rape of her daughter, she crossed the snow-capped heights of the nymphs of Mount Ida;
and in sorrow cast herself down in the rocky woods deep in snow; and, by not making fruitful with crops the barren fields of the earth for mortals, she destroyed the human race.
She would not send forth the rich nourishment of leafy tendrils for the herds, and life was leaving the cities. No sacrifice was offered to the gods, and on the altars were no cakes to burn;
she made the dew-fed springs of clear water cease flowing, the avenger in sorrow for her child.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: When she made an end to banquets for gods and the race of men, Zeus spoke out, appeasing the
Mother’s gloomy wrath: Go, holy Graces, go and with a loud cry take from Demeter’s angry heart her grief for the maiden;
and you, Muses, with song and dance. Then Kypris, fairest of the blessed gods, first took up the rumbling voice of bronze and the drum with tight-stretched skin; and the goddess smiled,
and received in her hand the deep-toned flute, pleased with its loud note.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: You made burnt offerings that were neither right nor holy, in the chambers of the gods,
and you have incurred the wrath of the great mother, child, by not honoring her sacrifices. Oh! Great is the power of dappled fawn-skin robes,
and green ivy that crowns a sacred thyrsos, the whirling beat of the tambourine circling in the air, hair streaming wildly for the revelry of Bromios,
and the night-long festivals of the goddess. . . . You gloried in your beauty alone.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: My friends, all goes well for us inside;

for the daughter of Proteus, who aids us in our theft, has told her brother nothing when questioned as to my husband’s coming; for my sake she said that he was not alive, but dead and buried. . . . My husband has snatched up by chance fine things indeed;

for he is carrying away the armor he was intending to let fall into the sea, putting his noble arm through the shield-strap and holding a spear in his right hand, on pretence of joining in the service to the dead. He has equipped his body with weapons conveniently for the battle,

in order to to set up the trophies of countless barbarians, whenever we embark on the oared ship. I adorned him with robes in place of his shipwrecked garments, and I washed him, a long-delayed bath in water from the stream.

But I must be silent, for the man is coming from the house who thinks he holds my marriage ready in his hands; and I claim your goodwill and strict silence, so that, when we have saved ourselves, we may be able some day to save you also.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Advance in order, servants, as the stranger directed, bearing the funeral gifts for the sea. But you, Helen, if you will agree with my words, be persuaded and stay here; for you will do your husband equal service whether you are present or not.

For I am afraid that some sudden passion should persuade you to throw your body into the swelling waves, stricken by love for your former husband; you are grieving for him too much, although he is lost.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: O my new husband, I must honor

my first marriage-bed and the one whose company I shared as a bride; for I could even die with my husband, I loved him so much. But how could he thank me, if I were to share death with him? Let me go and pay funeral rites to the dead in person.

May the gods give to you the things I wish and also to this stranger here, for his assistance! And you will have in me such a wife at home as you ought to have, since you are doing a good service to Menelaos and to me; for surely these events are leading to some good fortune.
But now appoint someone to give us a ship in which to carry these gifts, so that I may have your kindness in full.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: (to an attendant.)You, go and give them a Sidonian ship of fifty oars, and rowers also.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: This man who is ordering the funeral will be in command of the ship, won’t he?

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Most certainly; my sailors must obey him.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Repeat the order, so that they may clearly understand you.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: I repeat the order, and a third time too, if you wish it.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: May you have benefit from it—and I from my plans!

sp.speaker: Thoeklymenos
sp.l: Do not ruin your skin with too much weeping now.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: This day will show my gratitude to you.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: The state of the dead is nothingness; toil for them is vain.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: There is something of what I say both there and here.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: You will not find in me a husband at all inferior to Menelaos.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: You are not at fault in any way; good luck is all I need.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: That is in your power, if you show kindness to me.

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: This is not a lesson I shall have to learn now, to love my friends.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Would you like me to send out the equipment in person, working together with you?

sp.speaker: Helen
sp.l: Not at all! Do not become a slave to your slaves, lord.

sp.speaker: Theoklymenos
sp.l: Come then! I have no concern with the customs of the race of Pelops.
My house is pure; for Menelaos did not die here. Let someone go and tell my chieftans to bring marriage-offerings to my house; the whole earth must ring with joyful wedding-songs
